children.name: a large number of things or people
a lot
examples: ▪ I was surprised so few people were at the concert - I thought there’d be a lot there.

children.name: a lot of
examples: ▪ A lot of tourists visit Venice in the summer.
▪ John has lived in a lot of different places.

children.name: a lot more/fewer/less
examples: ▪ I’m sure she has a lot more problems than I have.

children.name: quite a lot
examples: ▪ There were quite a lot of words that I couldn’t understand.

children.name: a whole lot/an awful lot : nhiều hơn nhiều , ít hơn nhiều
examples: ▪ An awful lot of his customers are unhappy with his work.

children.name: lots
children.definition: a lot of people or things:
examples: ▪ ‘Have you gotten any responses to your ad?’ ‘Yeah - lots.’
lots of
▪ I’ve invited lots of people.
▪ She asked lots of questions during the interview.
lots and lots of
▪ They’ve planted lots and lots of flowers in the back yard.
lots more/fewer/lessl : nhiều hơn nhiều , ít hơn nhiều
▪ We get lots more people in the bar on Fridays.

children.name: many
children.definition: use this especially inquestionsandnegativesentences. Many is also used inpositivesentences inwrittenEnglish and informalspokenEnglish.:
examples: many questions/people/cars/thoughts etc
▪ Did you get many Christmas cards this year?
▪ I don’t know many people here, do you?
not many
▪ Not many people survived the crash.so many
▪ There were so many people at the party, I never even saw Will.
too many
▪ They’ve got too many rules for me to remember them all.
many ofmany among a large number of people or things
▪ Many of the paintings burned, but the most valuable ones were saved.
for many years
▪ She worked as a reporter with CBS news for many years.
in many ways/places/cases etc
▪ There will be rain in many parts of the country tonight.
many more/fewer/less
▪ We’ve had many fewer complaints since Doug took over the department.
the many
▪ The report hardly mentions the many patients who have benefited from the treatment.
a good many
▪ A good many scientists were opposed to the use of the bomb.
many a person/place/thing
▪ I’ve spent many a happy morning fishing from this spot.

children.name: a large number of
children.definition: /large numbers of  a lot of a particular type of person or thing - used especially innewspapersandofficialreports:

children.name: một số lượng lớn
examples: ▪ Police seized a large number of weapons.
▪ Large numbers of demonstrators were arrested during today’s protest march.

children.name: tonsalso loads especially British/masses British
children.definition: informal a lot of people or things:
examples: ▪ ‘How many strawberries did you pick?’ ‘Masses!’
tons of
▪ You can borrow one of my books if you want - I have tons of them.
▪ The beach was really crowded - there were loads of people from all over Europe.
loads and loads/tons and tons etc
▪ There were loads and loads of empty seats at the game - I was kind of surprised.

children.name: a bunch
children.definition: informal a lot of people or things:
examples: ▪ ‘Do you have any markers I could borrow?’ ‘I’ve got a bunch - what colors do you need?’
a bunch of
▪ Rita finally showed up with a bunch of her friends.
▪ I went to a bunch of different stores but I couldn’t find a coat I liked.
a whole bunch
▪ A whole bunch of us are going to the beach - you want to come along?

children.name: dozens
children.definition: a large number of people, things etc but not usually more than a hundred:
examples: ▪ At least five people died and dozens more were injured in a gas explosion just outside Paris.

children.name: dozens of
examples: ▪ Since we put the advertisement in the paper we’ve had dozens of phone calls.
▪ Baldwin was the author of six novels, four plays and dozens of essays and poems.

children.name: dozens and dozens
examples: ▪ The women see dozens and dozens of movies a year.

children.name: numerous
children.definition: many:
examples: ▪ The same problem has occurred before on numerous occasions.
▪ Numerous books and movies have dealt with the issue of wife abuse.
too numerous to list/mention/name etc
so many that you cannot say all of them
▪ I want to thank all the people, too numerous to mention, who’ve helped me win this election.

children.name: a host of
children.definition: a large number of things or people, especially when this is impressive or surprising:
examples: ▪ AIDS can indirectly result in a host of other illnesses.
▪ Since he was elected, the president has been faced with a host of difficult problems.

children.name: a whole host of
examples: ▪ Their newest compact model has a whole host of exciting new features.

children.name: quite a few
children.definition: a fairly large number of people, things etc:
examples: ▪ He’s been working at the company for quite a few years.
▪ There have been quite a few accidents on this stretch of road.
▪ ‘How many people are coming to the party?’ ‘Oh, quite a few.’
quite a few of
▪ She knows quite a few of the people who work at the hospital.

children.name: multi-coloured/multi-national/multi-storey/multi-racial/multi-purpose/multi-million dollar etc
examples: having or involving many colours, countries etc:
▪ My new office is in a multi-storey building.
▪ The company is a multi-national corporation, which has branches all over the world.
▪ Russia has moved from a one-party dictatorship to a multi-party system of government.

children.name: a raft of
children.definition: a large number of ideas, opinions, suggestions etc:
examples: ▪ The President has a raft of new proposals for dealing with inner city decay.

children.name: a whole raft of
examples: ▪ By the end of the meeting we had a whole raft of new ideas for expansion.

children.name: multiple injuries/wounds/burns/fractures
examples: in many parts of the body:
▪ She suffered multiple injuries after jumping out of a fifth floor window.
▪ Lauda was pulled from his blazing car with multiple burns.

children.name: a lot of
children.definition: a lot
examples: ▪ If you plan carefully, a trip to Europe doesn’t have to cost a lot.

children.name: a lot of
examples: ▪ We spent a lot of time just lying on the beach.
▪ The book contains a lot of useful advice about setting up your own business.

children.name: a whole lot/an awful lota very large amount
examples: ▪ To most Americans, $150,000 sounds like a whole lot of money.

children.name: quite a lota fairly large amount of something : khá nhiều
examples: ▪ Helen looks as if she’s lost quite a lot of weight recently - is she on a diet?

children.name: a lot more/less
examples: ▪ Ask Susan - she knows a lot more about computers than I do.

children.name: a lot to do/see/learn etc
examples: ▪ We’ve painted the kitchen and the living room, but there’s a lot to do in the other rooms.

children.name: lots
children.definition: a large amount of something:
examples: ▪ ‘How much money did you bring with you?’ ‘Lots.’
lots of
▪ It’s a big house, so we’ve got lots of room for company.
▪ There was lots of blood, but I don’t think anyone got killed.
lots and lots
▪ You can’t afford to stay there unless you’ve got lots and lots of money.
lots to see/do/learn etc
▪ You won’t be bored - there’s lots to do here.
lots more/less
▪ There’s lots more beer in the cooler if you want some.

children.name: much
children.definition: use this especially inquestionsandnegatives. Much is also used in positive sentences inwrittenEnglish and in formal spoken English:
examples: ▪ Do you know much about cars?
much pleasure/hope/sense etc
▪ It gives us much pleasure to announce the names of the winners.
▪ Her answer didn’t make much sense to me.
so much
▪ There was so much noise outside, I could hardly hear what she was saying.too much
▪ I think Perry’s had a little too much wine.
much to do/see/learn etc
▪ She never seems to have much to say.
▪ He’s very young and still has much to learn about how to deal with employees.
much more/less
▪ We’ve had much less rain this year than last year.
much ofa large part of something
▪ Much of Bangladesh remains flooded after last week’s torrential rains.

children.name: a great/a good deal of
children.definition: a great/a good deal  a large amount of something such as time, money, effort, or knowledge:
examples: ▪ We already know a great deal about the planet Jupiter.

children.name: a great/a good deal of
examples: ▪ The job requires a great deal of patience and skill.
▪ It sounds like a simple experiment, but it required a great deal of effort.
▪ There’s a good deal of evidence to show that eating red meat can cause heart disease.

children.name: a great/a good deal more/less
examples: ▪ Audiences have responded to his latest show with a great deal more enthusiasm.

children.name: quite a bit/a fair amountalso a fair bit British
children.definition: a large amount of something compared with the total amount that you have:
examples: ▪ Don knows a fair bit about managing a company.

children.name: quite a bit/a fair amount of
examples: ▪ I wasted a fair amount of time before I figured out what was wrong with the car.
▪ There’s been quite a bit of conflict between the new director and his staff.

children.name: quite a bit/a fair amount more/less
examples: ▪ The tickets will cost quite a bit less money if you stay over the weekend.

children.name: tonsalso loads especially British/masses British
children.definition: informal a very large amount of something:

children.name: ▪ ‘How much space is there in the back of your car?’ ‘Masses.’
examples: ▪ It was a fantastic meal - there was loads to eat.

children.name: tons of
examples: ▪ He made tons of money at some computer company.
▪ She’s a great athlete with loads of talent.
▪ I’ve got tons of homework to do this weekend.

children.name: tons and tons/loads and loads etc
examples: ▪ There’s tons and tons of information on the Internet if you’re willing to look for it.

children.name: piles/heaps/stacks
children.definition: informal a large amount of something, especially work or money:

children.name: ▪ ‘How much money have you saved?’ ‘Oh, stacks!’
examples: ▪ I have piles to do when I get home tonight.

children.name: piles/heaps/stacks of
examples: ▪ Her family is very rich - they have heaps of money.

children.name: a mountain of
children.definition: a large amount of something such as work, debt, or information:
examples: ▪ We had to complete a mountain of paperwork to get the loan.
▪ The economies of Third World countries are often crippled by huge mountains of debt which they will never be able to repay.

children.name: heavy
children.definition: a lot or in very large amounts, especially when this is worse than expected:

children.name: heavy rain/snow/traffic/fighting/losses/taxation
examples: ▪ The match went ahead despite the heavy rain.
▪ It was a fierce battle, and losses on both sides were heavy.
▪ Traffic was really heavy this morning - it took me over an hour to get here.

children.name: a bundle
children.definition: a large amount of money:
examples: ▪ He lost a bundle in the stock market.

children.name: a bundle of
examples: ▪ If you end up hiring a lawyer, it could cost you a bundle of money.

children.name: when there is a lot of sth in many areas
widespread
children.definition: having an effect on a lot of people over a wide area:
examples: ▪ Poverty in the region is widespread.

children.name: widespread damage/flooding/poverty etc
examples: ▪ Heavy rains have led to the most widespread flooding in a decade.
▪ Ethiopia was suffering widespread famine and disease.

children.name: extensive
children.definition: covering a large area or a large range of information, ideas etc:
examples: ▪ Damage to the forests from the wildfires was extensive.
▪ The ancient Greeks had an extensive knowledge of the stars.
▪ Abortion has been the subject of extensive debate in the US.

children.name: common
children.definition: if an object, animal, disease etc is common, there is a very large number or amount of objects, animals etc of this type in many different places:
examples: ▪ Jones is a very common name in Britain.
▪ Flatheads are a common type of fish and good to eat.
▪ Malaria is particularly common near swamps where mosquitoes can breed.

children.name: a very large number of people or things
hundreds of
children.definition: hundreds/thousands  a lot of things or people - use this when you want to emphasize that you are talking about a very large number. You can use this informally when the number is actually less than a hundred:
examples: hàng trăm hàng nghìn
▪ Hundreds were left homeless by the flood
hundreds/thousands of
▪ I’ve seen that movie hundreds of times.
▪ It will cost thousands of dollars to repair the house.
▪ From the 1880s to the early 1900s thousands of workers came to Hawaii from Japan.
hundreds and hundreds/thousands and thousandsalsohundreds upon hundreds/thousands upon thousands
▪ The temple was filled with hundreds and hundreds of lanterns.
by the hundreds/thousands
▪ Starving animals in the region are dying by the thousands.

children.name: a great many
children.definition: use this when you want to emphasize that you are talking about something important:
examples: ▪ We have seen a great many changes in the last twenty years.
▪ There are still a great many questions that remain unanswered.

children.name: a great many of
examples: ▪ The fire had destroyed a great many of the family’s possessions.

children.name: countless/innumerable
children.definition: an extremely large number of things or people, that cannot be counted or imagined:
examples: ▪ The mountains around the lake are filled with countless hiking trails.
▪ There are innumerable variations on the folktale, but the basic story is the same throughout Europe.
countless millions
an extremely large group of people
▪ His music has brought joy to countless millions.

children.name: everything but the kitchen sink
children.definition: an extremely large number of things of different types - use this especially when you think there are too many things:
examples: ▪ When my parents come to stay with us, they bring everything but the kitchen sink!
▪ Chatham refused to participate in what he called ‘everything but the kitchen sink’ art shows.

children.name: more than enough of sth that people need or want
plenty of
children.definition: plenty  a lot of something or a lot of things or people, especiallymorethanenough:

children.name: nhiều ( thừa )
examples: ▪ No thanks, I couldn’t eat any more. I’ve had plenty.

children.name: plenty of
examples: ▪ There’s plenty of room in the hall closet.
▪ We have plenty of glasses, but not enough plates.

children.name: plenty to do/eat/talk about etc
examples: ▪ The two men had plenty to talk about.

children.name: plenty of something to do something
examples: ▪ There’s still plenty of time to take a walk or a bike ride before dinner.

children.name: more than enough
children.definition: more than you need - sometimes used to mean there is too much:
examples: ▪ Here’s some money for the ticket - $25 should be more than enough.

children.name: more than enough something for somebody
examples: ▪ There’s more than enough food for everyone.

children.name: more than enough to do/think about etc
examples: ▪ I can’t help with the planning. I’ve more than enough to do already.

children.name: more than enough to do something
examples: ▪ He makes more than enough to live comfortably on.

children.name: more than enough something to do something
examples: ▪ Supporters have gathered more than enough signatures to put Fordham on the ballot.

children.name: bags of
children.definition: informal a lot or more than enough of something that you need or want:
examples: ▪ Don’t rush; we’ve got bags of time.
▪ The new manager is tremendously enthusiastic, and he’s got bags of new ideas.

children.name: ample
children.definition: more than enough:
examples: ▪ These documents provide ample evidence of their guilt.
▪ The program would ensure that Arizona has an ample supply of water for the next 20 years.
amply[adverb]
▪ The men have been amply rewarded for their services.

children.name: ample time/opportunity etc to do something
examples: ▪ You will have ample opportunity to express your opinions during the debate.

children.name: plentiful
children.definition: if something such as food or water is plentiful, there is more than enough of it available:
examples: ▪ During the summer tomatoes are plentiful and cheap.
▪ The river provides a plentiful supply of clean water to nearby villages.

children.name: an abundance of
children.definition: a large quantity of something, usually more than is needed:
examples: ▪ This book contains an abundance of valuable information.
▪ An abundance of fruits and vegetables grow in Kenya’s temperate climate.

children.name: abundant
children.definition: existing in large quantities so that there is more than enough:
examples: ▪ Latin America has an abundant labor force and natural resources.
▪ During the 18th century land was cheap, grain was plentiful, and meat was abundant.

children.name: abundant in
examples: ▪ Plant fossils are abundant in some types of rock.

children.name: galore
children.definition: available in large quantities - used especially in advertisements about something that people may want:
examples: ▪ There are bargains galore in our summer sale.
▪ Lots of fun for the kids! Rides and games galore!

children.name: a lot of unpleasant events in a short period of time
spate of st
children.definition: spate of something
examples: ▪ An alarming spate of bombings has caused widespread panic.
▪ The company has yet to respond to the recent spate of lawsuits filed against it.
▪ The party lost power three years ago after a spate of political scandals.

children.name: epidemic
children.definition: a lot of unpleasant activity of one particular kind which spreads quickly during a short period of time and which seems to be difficult to stop or control:
examples: epidemic of
▪ The recent epidemic of car thefts has been blamed on bored teenagers.
reach epidemic proportions
become like an epidemic
▪ Alcohol abuse has reached epidemic proportions in this country.

children.name: rash of st
children.definition: rash of something  a large number of unpleasant events or a particular kind that happen in a short period of time in many different places:
examples: ▪ Emergency officials worry that the region may again be hit by a rash of wildfires this fall.
▪ Experts are not sure what is causing the recent rash of mountain lion sightings.

children.name: wave
children.definition: a lot of unpleasant activity or actions suddenly becoming worse and increasing in a short period of time:

children.name: wave of
examples: ▪ Security chiefs fear a new wave of terrorist bombings.
▪ The country has been brought to a standstill by the latest wave of strikes.

children.name: crime wave
examples: ▪ The mayor has promised tough action in response to the city’s rising crime wave.

children.name: a lot of people or things all arriving at the same time
flood of
children.definition: a very large amount of something or a very large number of things or people arriving in a short period of time:
examples: ▪ Many fear that the flood of imports could weaken Britain’s economy.
▪ The town has been hit by a flood of visitors since it was featured in the movie.
▪ The company was launched amid a flood of publicity a year ago.

children.name: wave of
children.definition: a sudden increase in the number of people or things all arriving at the same time:
examples: ▪ There was a great wave of immigrants to the U.S. at the beginning of the 20th century.
▪ Students are responsible for sparking the latest wave of demonstrations.

children.name: deluge/avalanche of
children.definition: a very large number of messages, letters etc all arriving suddenly at the same time, especially when there are too many:
examples: ▪ He received a deluge of telegrams and messages of support from around the world.
▪ Insurance companies are bracing themselves for an avalanche of claims following the hurricane.

children.name: when a lot of people or things do sth at the same time
in large numbers
children.definition: use this to say that a lot of people or things do something, or go or appear somewhere all at the same time:
examples: ▪ During the dry season animals gather in large numbers around the water holes.
▪ Young people are leaving the countryside and moving to the city in large numbers.

children.name: in droves
children.definition: if people go somewhere in droves, they go in large numbers especially when this surprises you:
examples: ▪ Nurses are leaving the profession in droves.
▪ People came in droves to watch the fireworks display.

children.name: in force/strength
children.definition: if people go somewhere in force or in strength a lot of them go together so that there is a large number of them in a particular place:
examples: ▪ The police arrived in force to break up the crowd of demonstrators.
▪ If Latino voters turn out in strength for the next election, results could be very different.

children.name: by the hundreds/thousands
children.definition: if people do something by the hundreds or by the thousands very large groups of them are doing it at the same time:
examples: ▪ People in the drought-stricken region are dying by the hundreds.
▪ From all over the country, people came by the thousands to pay respect to their dead leader.

children.name: thick and fast
children.definition: if messages, events etc come thick and fast, a lot of them suddenly come or happen in a short time:
examples: ▪ At first no one was interested in the job but now applications are coming in thick and fast.
▪ Rumours flew thick and fast that the company was going to be sold.

children.name: be dying/dropping like flies
children.definition: to be dying or suddenly becoming ill in large numbers:
examples: ▪ In the middle of the cholera epidemic, people were dropping like flies.
▪ When Sam reached 70, it seemed his friends started dying like flies.

children.name: done or believed by a lot of people
common
examples: commonly[adverb]
▪ Aspirin is commonly used to relieve pain.
commonly known/understood/referred to as somethingknown by a lot of people or most people in a particular way
▪ He leads the Student Environmental Action Coalition, more commonly known as SEAC.

children.name: phổ biến
examples: ▪ Using ‘lay’ instead of ‘lie’ is a very common mistake.
▪ It’s becoming more and more common for women to keep their family name when they marry.
▪ My daughter says politics is boring, which is a common attitude among teenagers.

children.name: widespread
children.definition: done, believed or felt by a lot of people in many different places:

children.name: lan rộng , rộng rãi, ảnh hưởng sâu rộng
examples: ▪ There was now widespread public support for healthcare reform.
▪ The airlines’ failures were in part caused by widespread concern about air safety.
▪ The practice of adding preservatives to basic foods is widespread.

children.name: popular
children.definition: done, believed, or felt by a lot of ordinary people have:
examples: ▪ There is still a lot of popular support for the ex-president.
▪ I don’t accept the popular view that all criminals should be put in prison.
contrary to popular belief
the opposite of what most ordinary people believe
▪ Contrary to popular belief, the Australian desert is often full of wildlife. popularly [adverb] known, understood etc by a lot of ordinary people in a particular way::
popularly known/understood/referred to etc as something
▪ The law seeks to regulate smokeless tobacco, popularly known as ‘snuff.’

children.name: widely accepted/believed/known/practised/used etc
examples: done, believed or felt by a lot of people in many different places:
▪ Silicon Valley is widely known as California’s high-tech center.
▪ A hundred years ago it was widely believed that there was life on Mars.
▪ Asbestos was once widely used in the building industry.

children.name: when sb does sth a lot
a lot
examples: ▪ I’m really glad to meet you. Betty’s talked a lot about you.
▪ He really sweats a lot in hot weather like this.

children.name: a whole lot/an awful lot
examples: ▪ We didn’t do an awful lot while Geraldine was here.

children.name: quite a lot
examples: ▪ He laughed quite a lot as he spoke.

children.name: much
children.definition: use this in questions and negatives:
examples: ▪ I haven’t thought much about it.
▪ Do you talk to Leslie much anymore?

children.name: a good/great deal
children.definition: a lot:
examples: ▪ I’ve thought a good deal about what you said.
▪ Her knee makes it impossible to run, but she still walks a great deal.

children.name: quite a bit/a fair amountalso a fair bit British
children.definition: fairly often or in fairly large amounts:
examples: ▪ You’ve been travelling quite a bit lately, haven’t you?
▪ I exercise a fair amount - especially on weekends.
▪ You have to stand around a fair bit in this job.

children.name: heavy
examples: heavy smoking/drinking
smoking or drinking a lot, especially when this is bad for your health:
▪ She has a bad cough, caused by heavy smoking.
▪ The three soldiers are accused of killing the woman after a night of heavy drinking.
be a heavy smoker/drinker
smoke or drink a lot
▪ His first wife Joy was a heavy smoker who died of lung cancer.

children.name: be full of
children.definition: a)to contain many things of the same kind:
examples: a garden full of flowers
His essay was full of mistakes.
The music papers were full of gossip about the band.
Life’s full of surprises, isn’t it?
Her essay was full of mistakes.
be chock full of sthbe completely full of something
The pamphlet is chock full of advice for people travelling abroad.
b)to feel, express, or show a lot of a particular emotion or quality
full of excitement/energy/hope etc
Lucy was a happy child, alwaysfull of life.
He wasfull of praisefor the work of the unit.
c)to talk or think a lot about a particular thing :
She was full of plans for the wedding.

children.name: high
children.definition: something that is high in fat, sugar, salt etc contains a lot of fat, sugar etc:

children.name: high in
examples: ▪ The cereal is high in fiber and contains plenty of vitamin B.

children.name: high-fat/-sugar/-cholesterol etc
examples: ▪ I try to eat a low-fat, high-protein diet.

children.name: high metal/calcium/oxygen etc content
examples: ▪ The high oxygen content of Earth’s atmosphere makes life here possible.

children.name: rich
children.definition: something that is rich in a useful or valuable substance such as oil or iron, contains a lot of oil, iron etc:

children.name: rich in
examples: ▪ Spinach is rich in iron and very good for you.
▪ The land in this area is rich in minerals and ideal for growing crops.

children.name: oil-rich/copper-rich/diamond-rich etc
examples: ▪ Numerous companies sprang up employing thousands to work the oil-rich fields of Texas.

children.name: parched with
children.definition: packed with sthcontaining a lot of a particular type of thing:

children.name: a new magazine packed with exciting recipes
examples: This book is packedwithuseful information.

children.name: when there is a lot of unpleasant activity
be rife
children.definition: if something bad or unpleasant is rife, it is very common. If a place, situation, or activity is rife with something bad or unpleasant, the bad or unpleasant thing is very common there:
examples: ▪ Foreigners doing business in the city say that corruption is rife there.

children.name: be rife with
examples: ▪ The neighborhood is rife with illegal drug activity and violence.

children.name: be a hotbed of
children.definition: use this about a place where there is a lot of an activity, especially a bad or violent one:
examples: ▪ The political party has become a hotbed of nationalism and racial bigotry.
▪ The exhibition’s use of religious symbols has made it a hotbed of controversy.
